009package imagingbook.core.resource;
010
011import java.io.InputStream;
012import java.net.URL;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * This interface is supposed to be implemented by some enum class that
017 * specifies the root of a resource tree. The following example defines
018 * such an enum type that refers to three images. The path relative 
019 * to the location of the enum class itself must be specified
020 * and images must be stored there.
021 * The enum type must define an appropriate constructor and implement
022 * method {@link #getFileName()}:
023 * </p>
024
025 * <pre>
026 * public enum MyImages implements NamedResource {
027 *      image1("image1.tif"),
028 *      image2("image2.png"),
029 *      image3("jpegs/image3.jpg");
030 * 
031 *      // field to associate the resource's file name
032 *      private final String filename;
033 * 
034 *      &#64;Override
035 *      public String getFileName() {
036 *              return filename;
037 *      }
038 * 
039 *      // constructor
040 *      MyImages(String filename) {
041 *              this.filename = filename;
042 *      }
043 * }</pre>
044 * <p>
045 * By default, resource files are assumed to be placed in a folder
046 * with the same name as the resource class (i.e., "MyImages") relative
047 * to the location of the class.
048 * Resources may then be simply referenced by their enum-name, for example,
049 * </p>
050 * <pre>
051 * URL url = MyImages.image1.getURL();
052 * ImagePlus im = IJ.openImage(url.toString());
053 * </pre>
054 * <p>
055 * The benefit of using a named resource (over specifying resources by path strings) 
056 * is that the resource is guaranteed to exist at compile time (this is assured
057 * by validating the existence of all named resources in the test phase) and can be retrieved
058 * even if located inside a JAR file.
059 * </p>
060 * @see ImageResource
061 * @author WB
062 * @version 2022/08/23
063 */
064public interface NamedResource {
065        
066        /**
067         * Returns the resource directory relative to the implementing class.
068         * The default implementations assumes that this is a single-level directory
069         * with exactly the same name as the implementing class.
070         * Implementations may override this definition to return some other 
071         * relative directory.
072         * 
073         * @return the relative resource directory for the associated resource
074         */
075        public default String getRelativeDirectory() {
076                return getClass().getSimpleName();
077        }
078        
079        /**
080         * Returns the path to the associated resource relative to the
081         * location of the implementing class.
082         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
083         * 
084         * @return the relative path to the associated resource
085         */
086        public default String getRelativePath() {
087                return getRelativeDirectory() + "/" + getFileName();
088        }
089        
090        /**
091         * Returns the file name for the associated resource (to be implemented by
092         * concrete classes).
093         * 
094         * @return the name of the resource file
095         */
096        public String getFileName();
097        
098        /**
099         * Returns the URL to the associated resource. This method is not supposed to be
100         * overridden.
101         * 
102         * @return the URL to the associated resource
103         */
104        public default URL getURL() {
105                Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
106                return clazz.getResource(this.getRelativePath());
107        }
108        
109        /**
110         * Returns true if the associated resource (class) was loaded from a JAR file.
111         * 
112         * @return true if inside a JAR file
113         */
114        public default boolean isInsideJar() {
115                return ResourceUtils.isInsideJar(getClass());
116//              URL url = getClass().getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
117//              String path = url.getPath();
118//              File file = new File(path);
119//              return file.isFile();
120        }
121        
122        /**
123         * Returns an {@link InputStream} for reading from this resource.
124         * See also {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
125         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
126         * 
127         * @return an {@link InputStream} for the associated resource
128         */
129        public default InputStream getStream() {
130                return getClass().getResourceAsStream(getRelativePath());
131        }
132        
133        /**
134         * Returns the names of the actual files contained in the associated resource directory of
135         * the specified class, which must implement the {@link NamedResource} interface.
136         * This can be used to check if a given named resource has a matching file in a 
137         * case-sensitive way. 
138         * 
139         * @param clazz the resource class
140         * @return an array of strings
141         */
142        public static String[] getResourceFileNames(Class<? extends NamedResource> clazz) {
143                return ResourceUtils.getResourceFileNames(clazz, clazz.getSimpleName());
144        }
145
146}
